title: How to Do Cell Culture

steps.headline: Set up an aseptic work area and sterilize your equipment.
steps.description: Spray down your work surface and the inside of your cell culture hood with a 70% alcohol disinfectant spray. Hypochlorites, phenolics, and alcohols are also commonly used to sterilize equipment in a laboratory, but check to see what’s available in your laboratory. Remove any extraneous items from your work area to reduce clutter. Don’t store items in the same space where you perform cell cultures. Make sure to leave the cell culture hood fan turned on. Don’t turn it off unless the hood will not be in use for a long period of time. Check with a laboratory supervisor if you have questions about what to use to sterilize your work area.

steps.headline: Wash your hands and put on personal protective equipment.
steps.description: Use an antibacterial soap and warm water to wash your hands. Then put on gloves, a gown, goggles, a mask and any other require personal protective equipment for your experiment. Make sure to tie back your hair if it’s long so it will be out of the way.

steps.headline: Sterilize any reagents, solutions, or other media you will be using.
steps.description: This may involve using an autoclave or sterile filter. Check the guidelines for the type of media you are using before you try to sterilize it. Close the flask immediately after sterilizing the medium to prevent contamination.

steps.headline: Follow sterile handling procedures to prevent contamination.
steps.description: Contaminating your cell medium with chemical or biological agents can ruin the experiment. Chemical contaminants include detergents, water, endotoxins, and contaminants in the cell culture media. Biological contaminants include molds, yeasts, bacteria, viruses, and mycoplasma. To keep these contaminants out of your cell culture medium, always follow aseptic technique. For example, it’s best to use a pipette to transfer medium to your flask as pouring the medium in increases the risk of contamination.Tip: Always work slowly and deliberately to ensure that you are maintaining a sterile work space.

steps.headline: Select the appropriate cell line for your experiments.
steps.description:
You can acquire a wide range of animal cell lines from commercial or non-profit suppliers. Check to see what types of cells are available and choose the one that is best-suited for your experiment. Make sure that you choose a high-quality cell line to increase the chances of a successful experiment. Some criteria you may want to consider include:
The species of the cell
Functional characteristics of the cells
Whether you may need finite or continuous cell lines
The ideal growth conditions and characteristics
Whether you need normal or transformed cellsWarning: Never attempt to culture cells taken from someone working in the laboratory. Accidentally introducing these cells back into the person’s body could result in a malignant disease.

steps.headline: Go with an adherent culture for most cell types.
steps.description: Adherent culture is an artificial substrate that the cells are layered onto. This type of culture works best for the majority of animal cells since they require a substrate to rest on for proliferation. However, it’s best to check the specifications for the cell line you’re using to determine if you need this type of culture. After adding your medium to cells in an adherent culture, look at the cells under a microscope to see if they have released from the substrate. They will be spread out if they have released from the substrate.

steps.headline: Select a suspension culture for cells that have been adapted to it.
steps.description: With a suspension, the cells are not resting on anything. Instead, they are free-floating in liquid, which can make it easier to scale-up the culture with added medium. Some cell lines have been specifically modified to be used in a suspension, so check with the cell line manufacturer to be sure. A suspension medium is also a good option for cells that are not adhesive. Keep in mind that you’ll have to perform daily cell counts if you’re using a suspension cell culture.

steps.headline: Choose the culture medium that is best suited to your cells.
steps.description:
The ideal culture medium will vary depending on what type of cells you’re using. Check with the cell line manufacturer to determine the ideal cell culture medium for the cells you’re using. Some common types include:
Serum
Basal media
Reduced-serum media
Serum-free media

steps.headline: Check the pH and CO2 levels of the cell medium.
steps.description: The medium CO2 levels are best kept between 4-10% for all cell lines. However, the ideal pH level of the medium will vary according to the type of cells you’re using, so always check the pH level of your cell culture. Check with the cell line manufacturer to get details on the ideal pH level, or use common recommended pH levels for the types of cells you’re using. For example, mammalian cells grow best with a pH of 7.4, but insect cells grow best with a pH of 6.2.

steps.headline: Regulate the temperature to achieve the optimum environment.
steps.description:
Some cells will only thrive within a narrow temperature range, while other cells may thrive in a wider range of temperatures. Consider the type of cells you’re using and adjust the ambient temperature where you’re keeping the cells to the ideal level. Some common temperature recommendations include:
Human and mammalian cells- 36 to 37 °C (97 to 99 °F)
Insect cells- 27 °C (81 °F)
Avian cells- 38.5 °C (101.3 °F)
Cold-blooded cells- 15 to 26 °C (59 to 79 °F)

steps.headline: Count the cells using a hemocytometer right after you start a culture.
steps.description: A hemocytometer is a grid-like lens that goes over top of the cells under a microscope. This allows you to count the cells more easily by breaking the cells into quadrants and other smaller segments. Make sure to record the number of cells in each grid on the hemocytometer so that you can determine if the cells are multiplying the next time you count them. Tip: Use a clicker to make it easier to keep track of the number of cells in the culture.

steps.headline: Subculture the cells once they have doubled.
steps.description: After the cells in the medium have doubled in number, you can subculture them to continue their growth by dividing the cells into 2 containers and adding fresh medium to each one. Use the same type of substrate or suspension medium that you used for the initial cell culture. Divide the cells into 2 flasks so that half are in each one, then add 3 parts new medium to the container so that the medium is 25% old and 75% new.
